reviewText:
Cobalt is an action platformer with very satisfying combat mechanics.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-LQ__S1SiSM
The game is relatively easy to pickup, but there are a lot of tools given to you that if used properly, can give you the edge over your enemies. Timing and skill is quite important when it comes to combat, which makes it that much more satisfying.

First, I should mention that you can't aim freely in this game. You shoot wherever the character is facing, which is left or right. That is unless you hold the crouch or sneak button. That makes your character aim at the closest enemy automatically. That's how you can take out enemies on ceilings, or in the air. Your character will also auto-aim at enemies while you roll.

Rolling has other uses as too. If you roll into an enemy projectile, then you will deflect it and avoid taking damage. If it hits your head directly while rolling, then you'll deflect it at your enemy and in turn hurting them. However, if the projectile hits your feet while rolling, then you will take damage. It's little things like this that continue to make the gunplay interesting in this game.
One detail I love is that if you time it just right, you can punch the ground as you roll to launch yourself into the air.

Your arsenal consists of melee weapons, firearms and thrown objects. All of these add variety when it comes to destroying your foes. It's fun stuff!

There are two modes to choose from.
Story mode will have you making your way through huge levels, navigating different paths, completing puzzles, picking doors, discovering secrets etc. It's similar to other metroidvania" games if you want a more direct comparison. This mode is also sprinkled with a few cutscenes and dialogue

reviewText:
Wow, I have so many things to say I don't know where to start.

I started playing this game during its Alpha release, and from the moment I finished the tutorial, I knew this game had great potential. Not only was a stellar team working tirelessly to put such a complex game together, they were streaming their development process; There was always open communication between the devs and the community. Not only this, but they were backed by Mojang- A new testament to the reliability of small-team game developement.

Cobalt is a game of reflex, maneuverability and precision. There is no shortage of skills and strategy to be employed and the skill ceiling will leave casual gamers and veterans alike in awe of the possibilities of team composition, movement, vantage points, and finger dexterity.

One of the coolest features of Cobalt is the Time Dialation mechanic which slows time locally (relevant to each player) giving players more time to react to incoming projectiles. It is this mechanic (which I assume was a pain in the ♥♥♥ to get working consistantly for multiplayer) which enables players to perform feats which would simply be impossible in other platformer/shooters.

There is a copious amount of weapons, accessories, and characters ensuring that every thinkable playstyle can be catered to and employed successfully. This is especially useful for players hoping to customize their online experience, essentially allowing users to create their own classes in multiplayer matches and by extension, a new meta game for each lobby you join.

Fans of PVP gameplay will get hours of enjoyment from this title. A true test of gaming skill. Marvelous. Simply marvelous.

Everything is better with bullet time, and Cobalt is no exception. Oxeye's run-and-gun platformer has action, charm, and humour by the spadeload and is absolutely worth the asking price. It also has giant sabertooth space hamsters!

Battles in both singleplayer and online are chaotic and will often have unpredictable and hilarious outcomes, but you never feel that you've lost control. Time slows down as bullets and grenades get close to you, giving you the opportunity to execute a pixel-perfect dodge or perhaps even punch a grenade right back at whoever threw it! Facing a hail of bullets? No problem: do a combat roll straight into them and reflect them off the top of your robot's armoured head!

Although some people have commented that you need a gamepad, I'm getting on just fine with keyboard controls. For a right-handed person the defaults are pretty logical if you spend a couple of minutes in the tutorial to learn them, and are remappable if you find them awkward.

reviewText:
Cobalt is an achievement. This is something that can only be fully understood once you can play multiplayer deathmatch at sufficiently high level. I have played single player for 4 or 5 hours, but all of the rest was multiplayer deathmatch.

Because the combat in Cobalt is deep and refined.

Each minute decision of when to spin, when to jump, when to air jump, and on which direction, creates a *very* fluid and natural response in the player character. The result is that movement alone is a skill that you can spend hours upon hours mastering — and the range of possibilities is so vast that after practicing just movement for many hours (yes, I spent several hours jumping around alone in DM maps) the skill cap is still nowhere to be found.

On top of this, every weapon is its own delicious little niche of discovery. Take grenades, for instance. The path trajectory of grenades is influenced by your movement in multiple ways: (1) grenades will go further the longer you press the fire button; (2) grenades will inherit the speed at which your character is moving; (3) spinning allows you to throw grenades on any direction by correctly timing the release button, and (4) some grenades bounce off walls, some explode on impact, some get stuck to walls. These four factors multiply into *so many* possibilities! With the right sense of the thing, you can learn to place a grenade almost anywhere at almost any moment, with a good idea of when it will blow up. Someone is about to fall on top of you? Spin an explode-on-impact grenade directly above while falling down. Opposite team is rushing through a fixed path in large numbers? Spin a grenade in a long, tall arc to stall them from a safe position. Grenade throwing is a huge skill all in itself, and can make or break an entire game.

Or take punching, for another unpopular example. To properly punch your adversary requires a mix of timing, prediction (of what he will do), jumping and spinning (to avoid his shots), so that if you can do it properly the visual end-result looks as if a robot ninja from hell is warping a vortex of pure kung-fu on his unwitting prey. If you add on top of that that punching the ground or the wall will push you away from it, you will come to realize that even the damned melee weapon is beautifully designed.

And I could go on... I'm sure there is plenty of things I didn't discover!

Let me give you two parting tips for playing multiplayer: You can configure your keyboard to have three different keys for immediately shooting each category of weapon (melee, fire, grenade), and three different keys for selecting the weapon in each category. (By default cobalt you have three keys for selecting the weapon in each category and one fire key to fire the weapon in the category that was last selected; this will become a roadblock if you keep at it)

Much luck and have fun,
Bruno

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough!

If the trailer is of any indication, this game is action-packed. Play story mode a bit (or a lot because there are loads of things to do), play a variety of gamemodes with your friends, including classic deathmatch, but also original gamemodes like Plug Slam, where the object is to get the 'ball' into the opponents goal by any means necessary (think throwing, shooting, exploding).

The singleplayer modes are plenty difficult, and you will come across situations where you're surrounded by legions of robots and because you were stupid like me, forget to stock up on ammo and have to resort to punching them to death (which is difficult but you feel like a badass when you succeed). This is one of the most fun parts of the game: you can do some crazy ninja ♥♥♥♥ and kick some real ♥♥♥ once you get good at it. And you never stop becoming better at it.

Most gamemodes are also available online, which is also loads of fun when you don't have friends. There is also an extremely expansive map editor, which can lead to amazing things if you think creatively. I learn new things everytime I open it.

The visuals are great and the weapons feel very satisfiying to use. The soundtrack is brilliant and really fits the game well! I've almost never had problems with lag either, and if I did, it was because I created a tower of about 30 giant mech robots all firing homing missiles stacked on top of eachother in the editor.

The only issue I see with the game (and it's arguable it's even the games fault) is that there aren't that many players. This means you'll only see a couple online games at a time. Still, the most popular gamemodes (TeamStrike and Survival) always have at least one open game so it's bearable.

I've played this game for around 250 hours back when it was in alpha.
Helped testing some pre-releases and got a map into the final game.
Now that it's officially out on steam, my opinion isn't at all different than how it used to be all this time:

Cobalt is an incredibly fun game with some unique mechanics that really makes it a ton of fun to play.
The online multiplayer can only be a step in the right direction for the entertainment you'll get from the game, same goes for the pretty in-depth story mode.

Even with the new engine, it plays pretty much the same, except it supposedly has better performance (and a much improved selection of options!).

The only negatives I have to give it for now is that you can not play the story mode on online multiplayer, but only on local co-op, which is quite a shame since it seems like a ton of fun to play it with friends (you can't even play survival or challenge mode online, unless I'm mistaken). reviewText:
I bought this game on Jan 2nd 2012

After a long dev process and failed promises of linux and MacOS ports,  admin abuse of stupid forum rules that almost eroded any remaining community surrounding the game beyond the devs themselves.. and the acquisition of Oxeyes parent company by Microsoft. We have Cobalt.

It is a wonder that this game ever made it through development and despite my gripes with the team involved, they obviously love the game and have put their heart and soul in to it. The game now features a story mode with lots of hidden secrets, great puzzles and some very geeky if not a little clunky, dialogue.

Multiplayer can be a really fun experience of total mayhem, and yet I have still always enjoyed my solo runs more. Take from that what you will, but Cobalt as an experience definitely has a lot to offer.

Worth noting that I have a controller and yet choose to play with the keyboard, so don't let the prospect of that deter you.

I believe this is a game that could have benefited from steams EA program  but I understand why they didn't or couldn't go for it.. Especially after how rigidly they policed development through their own medium, I can imagine had they been so totalitarian on the steam forums this game would have a bag of negative reviews already.

That being said as a new comer you don't need to have any dealing with Oxeye at all. This is a finished product and while arguably a tad overpriced at this point (I paid closer to £5, 4 years ago). I still feel it an easy recommendation to those intrigued by the prospect of a skill based side scroller.

reviewText:
I discovered Cobalt a few years back at Minecon 2013, Jens and the other developers at Oxeye were operating a pretty cool panel about the game. Fast forward two weeks, I had purchased the alpha of the game and vested a good 20 hours into it.

Cobalt's emergence from alpha has been a progressive and evident one. This 'version 1.0' of Cobalt is chuck-full of features that make the game limitless in fun and interest: multiplayer is awesome, and the story mode is quite imaginative as far as platformers go. The map designs by the developers are just the tip of the iceberg, as you can design your own maps & levels.

$20 is not too much, might I add, for a game that has this extensive amount of gameplay. I have already sunk countless hours, and I'm not kidding when I say this game is still highly playable after 2 and a half years of playing it. It has a novelty, succession of updates, and evident quality.

That doesn't necessarily mean that Cobalt is 110% awesome, however. There is a learning curve and rather difficult controls. However, some messing around and patience is sure to get you a control setup you will enjoy. I find that anyone that complains of the game's controls has always proven impatient or ends up enjoying the game once they grasp the understand of 'how to play.' The great thing is that the controls are customizable and I understand gamepad support is available.

Overall, the game has an outstanding blend of fast-pace and slow-mo shooting action, accompanied by some great creative direction in design. As far as platformers go, there are few as good as Cobalt. As far as combat platformers go, there are none as good as Cobalt. The novelty, playability, design, and organic gameplay that Cobalt provides is one of the most unique and imaginative platformers around. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
First Impressions Video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j8m_prqz0g4

Cobalt surprised me.  I came in expecting another side scrolling shooter and found a much more intricate and complex design with some real character to it.  The graphical design is stylized and matched by ambient as well as beat heavy music.  The audio thump of weapons firing, punches connecting and robots being gibbed is satisfying every single time.
It is easy to tell that this is a labour of love.  Oxeye has been working on this game for 6 years, and it shows.  With multiple single player and multiplayer methods of playing, and the idea of having a full toolset to make your own levels is really cool.  So far, this title is an interesting diamond in the rough.

That’s not to say that it is without problems.  The review build I was provided by Oxeye seems to not recognize options changes.  I couldn’t change resolution or graphical quality.  The toolset opened to scripting errors and I did have the occasional crash when attempting to make options adjustments.

All of that said, for $20 you can do a hell of a lot worse and if it gets a large enough install base to where the multiplayer maintains an active community, I could see this game lasting quite some time to take advantage of those free updates Oxeye has promised.  I look forward to seeing what else Mojang might consider publishing.

reviewText:
Cobalt is a fun enough action platformer shooter, yet felt like a case of quantity over quality.

It starts out like a pleasant Metroidvania, where you're sent to explore a lost colony to find out what happened. It proceeds much like a Metroidvania, except that the journey is a purely linear one with no abilities to unlock to open new areas to explore.

The controls are a little odd. You have to hold Up or Down in order to aim, which stops your movement unless you're sliding down the hill. To melee you have to first hit X to switch to melee and then hit RT to attack, instead of X just being a dedicated melee button.

And then we come to the first boss fight, an exercise in going around a large room activating consoles while killing constantly respawning enemies. It's about as fun as it sounds, and it first introduces Cobalt's frenetic, chaotic combat, where you need to roll to deflect shots, shoot / hit incoming explosives to deflect them, and to pray. Success seems equal parts skill and luck as you're rolling and blasting and hoping you kill everything.

And after defeating the first boss, you get to do it all over again 5 more times, go through a similar set of maps to reach the same exact boss fight, just in a different room with different respawning enemies.

This is where the quantity over quality makes itself felt. Each of the 6 areas plays out exactly the same, with the same exact un-interesting boss fight at the end of each one. There's a plethora of weapons to collect, each with more stats than you'd find in an ARPG, but few are truly memorable. There are likewise armor upgrades, 5 items for 5 slots, that feature such dramatic differences as a 0.4 increase in damage reduction.

There are even animal enemies to summon or tame and ride, but they're all disposable.

And then there are bugs, from small things like how the Time Guardian never introduced himself and yet my character referred to him as such, to the game breaking bug after beating the 2nd boss fight. An item was supposed to spawn, but didn't, leaving me stuck and having to quit out and repeat the fight. I similarly got stuck in another area where I couldn't get out and couldn't progress until I brute forced a combination lock.

reviewText:
I've owned Cobalt for quite some time, since it was first released in Alpha. Back when Mojang could do no wrong and Notch was a god in the gaming world.
It's a tight little action platformer, with fairly unique mechanics and deep gameplay. Had a lack of content, polish, and major bugs, but the core concept was solid. I played it on and off for a few months, then forgot about it for years until it got its full release on Steam. I redeemed my code from the alpha version, and tried it out.
This game, at a 20$ price point, is unbuyable. It lacks content, and has so many game breaking bugs I would call it an Alpha rather than a full release. I've crashed no less than 16 times playing for a little over an hour, and encountered odd lag in multiplayer. The controls for keyboard are awful, and overcomplicated, so I played on controller, which was mediocre at best. The story seems fine, albeit not voice acted or interesting apart from the gameplay, and the multiplayer is night unplaybly buggy. The funnest part of Alpha Cobalt was removed (the survival mode, like Horde mode/COD Zombies), so I can't really rate that. This game has good core gameplay, but lacks in controls, stability, and content.
If this were priced at 10$, you might actually find some people to play with in the multiplayer, which is dead (3-4 players online at peak hours.). I got a good game of multiplayer in with 6 others once, and that was fun. For now, I'm going to give this game a thumbs down.
People who like the idea of this game, try out Duck Game. It's great. Really great.

reviewText:
Upon typing this up I realized how hard it actually is to describe Cobalt. But I'll try my best. Cobalt is a platform-shooter game. There's singleplayer modes and multiplayer modes, as most of you have come to expect in shooter games. But Cobalt adds in battle mechanics that are not comparable to any other game. There's rolling, extremely satasfying (I probably spelt that wrong, didn't I?) matrix-style slow mo, more rolling, interesting aiming mechanics, more rolling, and generally just a lot of rolling.

The keyboard controls seem a tiny bit weird at first- seems a little more like a browser game then a Steam game- but I've actually gotten used to it after not very long, and you can modify them if you're not happy. There's also different ways to play the game. There's campaign, which can be played by yourself or with someone else too. There's local multiplayer, which can be played by yourself against bots or with people on your wi-fi. And of course, there's multiplayer, which needs no explination. There's also gamemodes for multiplayer (local and normal multiplayer), which is where it gets interesting.

Free For all is self explanitory- every blueface for themselves. There is team options though.

Team Strike is team deathmatch- bluefaces unite. You can't respawn, but appearantly you can take over bots when you die. I'm unfamiliar with this gamemode, as I usually free for all with teamed.

Plug slam is like Uplink for you COD Advanced Warfare fans- you try to get a plug into a goal. Simple enough, but a lot of fun.

Survival Mode is where you have to fight off waves of robots. Yeah, I don't know a lot about this gamemode either.

Combat and speed challenges-err... I know nothing about them. :P But the name is kinda self-explanitory.

Campaign is also a lot of fun. You play as Agent Cobalt who is trying to find out what happened to a human settlement. But there's more to it. You can go to dances for no reason whatsoever, roll, train endlessly for combat even though you are already a master at it, roll, make friends with birds and feel bad about life when they die, and more rolling. I hope you like rolling, cause if you do you're in for a treat with this game.

Overall, this game gets 9/10. 1 off because although the game explains the mechanics really well, it does leave you with a few blanks in campaign, which meant I had to try and figure it out myself, and ain't nobody got time for dat!

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since day 1, when they released the first alpha build. I can honestly say it's in my top 10 games of all time. I have 100s of hours not logged on steam from all the years.

The two main parts of the game, that make it stand out from all other titles, is: Slow-Mo and Rolling. These two mechanics combine to make one of the most unique and satisfying experiences I've had in gaming.

With the main points out of the way, some pros:

-Endless replayability.
-Enjoyable learning curve.
-Quirky and beautiful graphics.
-Enough gamemodes to keep you engaged.
-The soundtrack is minimalistic but genius.
-Story mode, which I can't really comment on since I haven't completed, but so far it's great.
-Local Co-op, so if you've got some friends to play with it takes the game from awesome to REALLY awesome.
-Tooooons of different weapons to get acquainted with, everything from machine guns to scimitars, sticky mines to plasma pistols, tazers to wrenches, rocket launchers to sniper rifles, and everything in between. No matter your preferred combat style, your needs will be met with the vast array of weaponry. Not to mention other gadgets to augment your experience, such as jet shoes and shields.
-You can ride giant carniverous space hamsters.
-Steam Workshop, so users can make maps.
-The best pro is that there are no cons.

So yeah. I urge anyone who's looking for a fresh kind of game to pick it up right now. Worth every cent.

reviewText:
This is my first review for a game. I don't usually write reviews, but I felt like I should weigh in on this.

Bottom-line: this game's good.

It's pretty difficult, but it depends on your skill as a player, rather than artificial difficulties (like traps, attacks you couldn't see coming, etc). The music's nice and atmospheric, and keeps up the tension as you explore the game world, looking to avoid getting overwhelmed by multiple soldiers. The graphics are crisp and high-detail, and the game's pretty well optimized, to boot.

The multiplayer's surprisingly lagfree and is pretty deep, as well - for example, rolling can change how and when you attack, and also reflects bullets. So it's pretty much mandatory if you want to play singleplayer, even more-so online. However, rolling all of the time becomes a burden, like dodging or blocking all of the time in a fighting game, as when you're in a roll, you can't stop rolling, and a shot that hits your feet will damage you. So you have to mix it up, time your rolls, and move around to avoid dying, haha.

There's a ton to do in the game, and there's room for improvement, as there's also additional game modes that are present on the Workshop maps. For example, Classic Survival mode is not like the regular Survival mode. In Classic Survival, you don't face off against discrete waves, but rather deal with enemies as you explore the game map, searching hidden alcoves and safes for loot and weapons. Classic Survival's probably my favorite game mode, haha.

Anyway, my opinion's that this game is EASILY worth more than $20. Get it!

reviewText:
On paper, Cobalt is fairly simple. You are a robot dude, and you shoot other robot dudes and things. When a bullet, grenade or other hazard comes close, time locally slows down around you, giving you time to punch that grenade back, deflect that bullet or pull some otherwise epic combo. Trust me, this is way more fun than it sounds.

With the high skill ceiling on all aspects of the game (timing shots, throwing bombs, punch jumping, etc) there is a lot to learn but the game is pretty easy to pick up and has plenty of things to do such as a detailed campaign, speedrun challenges (against the rest of the world), wave survival, plug football (except you can throw it) and good old deathmatch.

Brilliant gameplay, and I also like the graphics style. I would recommend this to anyone who likes action and pulling cool stunts and general awesomeness. There is plenty for both competitive and casual players.

Get it. Get it now.
